title: Will any disputes over IAEA access to Iranian sites be referred to the Joint Commission before 1 July 2018?
preds: passage of time; no impetus on any actor to take this action at this time
Adjusting down for passage of time
At this point, I do not believe that a dispute will be referred to the commission by the deadline, since there are basically no incentives for Iran to decline access in the next month.
The deal is off, no need for inspection until further notice.
Given I think we are exiting, I don't see this mattering any more.

Believe point of this question is Iran allowing access to their sites. All parties agree Iran has allowed access to sites to letter of agreement. There has been question Iran is not honouring spirit of agreement (probably true) but doubtvagreement will fail due to access issues (unless as part of an escalation and Iran says, ok we’re done- not allowing you access any longer...)
Rising to 5% on notion that Macron of France might go there as it is a forum he is comfortable with, and represent U.S. concerns.
The nuclear deal only helps Iran to rebuild their economy. I don't see any positive outcome by restarting a nuclear program. So far Iran has done nothing but adhere to the nuclear deal.

Most probable, the deal will be terminated before July, wich would end the possibility of taking any disputes to the Joint Comission, or the Iran will keep its commitment and compliance with the deal, giving no reason for the IAEA to complain about access to Iranian sites. But there is a tiny possibility that the US press the IAEA to stress to Iranian government and taking a dispute to the Joint Commission, giving the US an excuse to terminate the deal.

Most agree the deal is a a bad one but perhaps best possible? Regardless of what happens to deal, unlikely it will come undone due to access issues...
https://www.economist.com/news/international/21739646-john-boltons-appointment-national-security-adviser-sounds-its-death-knell-deal?frsc=dg%7Ce

America and Iran seem to be heading for a conflict, which may not necessarily be physical  but could be diplomatic,  and the issue of access to some of Irans military sites is high on America's agends

I think we have to consider the possibility that a active complaint might be used to encourage the US. to stay with it. I don't think it will work though as we may be setting a demonstration for NK about what happens if we think their offer is a bad deal.

I realize challenges re access to military sites. Flip side is USA wants to negotiate with NK so you’d think would want to be seen as a “deal-maker” which would be more challenging if you appear whimsical re nuke disputes and monitoring.

The Iran deal's inspection regime has so far worked out relatively well, and Iran has not "caused trouble" for inspectors to generate disputes for the joint commission. Considering the benefits, especially the lifting of economic sanctions Iran has enjoyed since reaching the nuclear deal, it's very unlikely that by July 2018 Iran would change course and provoke the IAEA. However, though President Trump has not yet repealed the Iran deal, he has always held a hard-line position on Iran, and his recent nomination/appointment of fellow hardliners John Bolton and Mike Pompeo as NSA and Secretary of State could bring radical changes to US's Iran policy. Were the US to sabotage the Iran deal by adopting provocative tactics like demanding inspection of Iranian military facilities, disputes could be generated for the joint commission.

I believe that the US is looking for any excuse to abrogate the Iran deal. With John Bolton installed as Trump's security advisor, the pressure is even greater. If they need an "excuse" to abrogate the deal, they will create a dispute, which will go to the IAEA, which will be pilloried by the right wing in the US and the US will ignore any findiings. Rinse. Repeat.
I am slightly upgrading likelihood with the appointment of John Bolton as US Nat'l Sec Advisor.
Increasing to consensus given American foreign policy and dislike of Iran (“success” in getting North Korea to table). May increase further.

While the Republican members of Congress and Donald Trump have been vocal about their dissatisfaction with the JCPOA, other states who are part of the agreement want to see the deal upheld, including the E3. Tehran, likewise, wants to see the deal honored. Concerned about the possibility of the reimposition of sanctions, Iran is not in a position to deny access to IAEA inspectors or be party to any disputes over access to Iranian nuclear sites. According to the Islamic Republic News Agency, Deputy Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi said recently "Our stance is clear and unwavering. The JCPOA can never be reopened, renegotiated or re-discussed. In our view, there can exist no supplemental agreement, amendment or anything to that effect under any different wording." The 8th Joint Commission met in Vienna this week and there doesn't seem to be anticipation of referral of disputes over IAEA access.
DT seems more interested in undermining the deal than working inside it.
The August 2017 report indicates IAEA personnel have been allowed access to relevant sites. This appears unlikely.
The US has no influence under Trump.
I believe Iran is playing it straight.

I have not even hear of one violation ? 
By Erin Cunningham August 31, 2017 authored an article stating that Iran is not violating the accord  
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/iran-adhering-to-nuclear-deal-with-world-powers-un-watchdog-says/2017/08/31/cb408e7d-bc9a-4874-bbdf-001f919a8c86_story.html?utm_term=.9400b9da2ff7
Well I got this one totally wrong. Obviously a bias - must have been a lot of anti-Iran sentiment around when I made the prediction in late September.
They appear to have every intention of adhering to the agreement.

With all of the other issues surrounding the JCPOA, Iran is unlikely to give the United States another reason to undermine the implementation of the agreement. The recent protests in Iran over government actions make it unlikely Tehran will go outside the scope of the deal and risk another round of protests if Western states take action against Iran. This is especially true given the rather large latitude Iran has to work with within the scope of the agreement. Iran will not risk additional economic sanctions in order to keep IAEA inspectors out of the facilities.
There is no indication any requests have been made.

Given that the JCPOA permits Iran to continue substantial nuclear activity and does not require it to disclose past work, and that Iran has a track record of deception, robust inspections are necessary to provide confidence that its nuclear weapons work has not resumed. The JCPOA provides significant authorities to International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) inspectors - the key is that they be interpreted expansively and applied aggressively.
No indication that step is under consideration.
Assessing at 2%, Iran has appeared very willing to remain within the bounds of the agreement that they made.

Drastically reducing likelihood because I think I understand the question better now. When the deal was made, the US side observed that they had to be very specific because the Iranians are notorious for finding loopholes--they will abide by the letter of the agreement at the expense of the spirit of the agreement. Given the Iranians have a 14-day window to avoid having an issue referred to the JC, that's probably enough time for them to ready any site they might want to prepare of no-notice inspections making it less likely they would allow it to come to a JC referral. I didn't see too many comments and even fewer constructive comments on this topic, so would be grateful for any constructive criticism of my thought process.
Strong incentives for Iran to work with E3 to sustain deal; mistakes however remain possible

The IAEA [International Atomic Energy Agency] has confirmed in nine reports that Iran is fully complying with the commitments made under the agreement.
https://www.google.com.au/search?q=IAEA+access+Iran+Joint+Commission&safe=off&client=ubuntu&hs=NFh&channel=fs&dcr=0&source=lnt&tbs=qdr:w&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiPqNroj_zYAhWHk5QKHQb-D38QpwUIIQ&biw=1853&bih=1071

It doesn’t seem likely that Iran will want to risk having disputes referred to the Joint Commission especially as it is trying to present itself as a stable place for businesses to invest in order to boost it’s economy.
not specific to question but based on Iran vs US and US allies relationship not getting worse

The article doesn’t necessarily help, but interesting perspectives...everyone is fine with the flawed agreement except for one orange guy. And his opinion counts. Maybe someone should tell him there are sharks in the water over there...

This is getting trickier. Political considerations work in favor of both sides. If we see IAEA acknowledging a dispute and acting on it - it makes it harder for DT to withdraw from the agreement - or does it? It could just as easily be used to say Iran is at it again. I am holding at 5% and watching for any hint of an access complaint. The inside and outside views are colliding. Comments invited (that means you Dsarian)
Trump administration will want to establish a basis for withdrawing from the nuclear agreement (or demanding renegotiation). May happen later, though, for the optics prior to the midterm elections.

The US State Department will bring pressure on the IAEA to do more inspections.
No reason I can think of for the Iranians to provoke any such confrontation.  They can just be patient and ride out the moratorium.
I judge the likelyhood extremely minimal in current political situation and based on the recent positive achievements.

Moving this up from 0 after recent events. I'm still convinced Iran has never had any desire to try to get a nuclear weapon.
I don't think the situation has fundamentally changed since last year - even the USA say that Iran is JCPOA compliant, despite Trumps desire to decertify.

I downgrade my former forecast because the there has not been any obstacle for the IAEA inspection. In fact, USA government has been incapable to base its arguments against Iran in something more factual than the general assertion that Iran is a menace to the regional stability.

For a referral there needs to be real evidence of Iranian violations as judged by by the IAEA and Iran must then refuse access to the IAEA. The precise procedures for this have been designed by experts who were well aware of how things went wrong in the case of the UN's investigation of the WMD in Iraq. This alone makes it unlikely for a dispute to arise. But we must also consider that Iran currently doesn't engage in sensitive nuclear activities about which misunderstandings or disputes could arise. Indeed, the Trump Administration is invoking the fact that Iran will be allowed to resume some of the more sensitive nuclear work in 2025 and some more in 2030, without making it clear that this is under strict supervision. As things stand now, with Iran verifiable not using its nuclear infrastructure, Iran would have to engage in some stand alone nuclear activity at some secret location. There is little point for Iran to go about doing that.

This is not a change from my earlier forecast. The comprehensive historic report the IAEA came out with I think in December of 2015 stated that there was no evidence that Iran had ever attempted to get a nuclear weapon or build a nuclear weapon. Iran has violated UN sanctions by conducting missile tests but that is a separate matter from this treaty. Except for one month where Iran had too much heavy water because the US refused to buy it like they agreed to, Iran has been completely in compliance with the treaty. The only reason why there would be a contested site is if Trump is looking for a reason for a conflict, but I think it's just as likely that Trump would pull us out of the treaty altogether. I believe any contested site would be a false flag accusation. The last few decades has had scores of those. While I do think it is likely the US will go to war soon in order to distract the public and because the powers-that-be believe it stimulates the economy, I think it is more likely to be with North Korea or Russia or Venezuela. We invaded Iraq shortly after Iraq decided to no longer sell oil in dollars, and now that Venezuela has done the same I think they are the most likely target. No country in history has ever had as much scrutiny on its nuclear program as Iran has now.

For a dispute to be referred to the commission the Iranian nuclear deal must still be in place then either Iran unreasonably blocks access to the IAEA or US demands access to military sites that then Iran refuses to give access to. 
Trump has not only said he would consider leaving the nuclear deal, he also has shown he is not afraid to leave international arrangements (Paris Agreement and TPP) and is also not afraid to renegotiate international deals with the case of NAFTA. Leaving such an important deal for US safety seems reckless, even for Trump, so I would put the chance of leaving the nuclear deal at 7%. The chance of renegotiating the Iranian nuclear deal within the seems considerably higher as it allows for Trump to hit home his nationalist credentials without severely risking Iran gaining nuclear weapons. This could trigger a Iran to block IAEA access during renegotiation to show strength - I give this a chance of 1%. 
Chance of Trump referring to the joint commission because IAEA not allowed access to certain military facilities, assuming deal isn't broken - 2% 
Iran blocking IAEA access otherwise could be because 1. They are breaking the nuclear agreement with hope to build nuclear weapons 2. They want to agitate US or show strength to Middle Eastern rivals. Point 1 is very unlikely as Iran would have very little to gain from developing nuclear weapons due to US deterrence as seen by the Iraq war (caused by blocked access to UN inspectors) and Trump's tough talk on North Korea. Chance of point 1 is <1%. Point 2 seems credible, especially given heating up conflict with Saudi Arabia with the Qatari blockade, Yemen and Syrian civil wars. However, it comes with great risks of costly retaliation and sanctions that forced Iran into the nuclear deal in the first place. I give point 2 a probability of 6%. 
Calculated probability comes out at 8.4% so round up to 10% due to Iran's history of being difficult with inspectors and due to not including the chance of point 1 in the calculation.

Because 1) It's seems clear that Trump is willing to change the status quo with Iran. 2) It appears clear, also, that Trump has decided to avoid unilateral actions in international affairs, despite his rhetoric. In N.Korea, Syria and Venezuela, he has tied to force the other players to follow him, using bilateral and multilateral sittings. Until now, besides the modest outcome, there are no signals that he is changing his way. In consequence, in order to advance his goals again Iran, he could try to use any disagreement about the implementation of the deal, for example, interferences with the IAEA task coming from Iran side to activate the JComission. That is a way to build  support from the key players for further measures aimed to strength pressure against Iran. 3) So, there are good reasons to believe that something will append. But, due to dynamics of international affairs, the many fronts that Trump must deal (both, international and domestic),  a higher probability is a rash forecasting

Unless Iran throws the inspectors out, or bans them from previously agreed sites,  Disputes are only likely to occur re: visit to military sites.  Note that IAEA does not have blanket permission to visit any of the previously identified (nor any new) nuke research/enrichment sites designated as "military" by Iran.  This would only be allowed under the "additional protocol", which Iran has never signed but the IAEA claims is in effect.   Currently, the must seek Iran's permission to visit the site, and have "evidence" supporting the reasons for the proposed visit to a military site . Of course, how does one get "evidence" without access  (usually only through an accident that releases detectible radiation, construction of an identifiable structure- not likely for research/enrichment conducted underground, or through espionage/inside information).   In the latter case (info gathered through espionage or via Iranian sources), revealing this info to the IAEA is usually not the initial course of events (even less so for this Trump admin).

Iran granted access to its facilities without bigger problems. The work done so far is accepted IAEA. The biggest problem will be the US ending the deal one-sited. With this in mind the Iran will keep up to earn some points with the EU and UN to get some more resolutions lifted.
The Iranian Republic has been quite defensive on the topic lately. The only possibility I see for this happening is if Trump keeps escalating the topic.

Never say never with the theocracy but the US's recent softening of some sanctions will only strengthen the case for de-escalation.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Even if there are future access problems, its highly unlikely that IAEA would characterize such access problems in terms that would facilitate a USG demand to refer Iran to the Joint Commission.   No party to the JCPOA (beyond the USG) seeks such an escalation.

assumption:  I start with the assumption that Iran never discontinued work on their nuclear program.  Given the limitations of the JCPOA, the more than 80 billion in USD already unfrozen, and the large investments by European companies that will make "snap back" an impossibility, I see no reason why Iran would comply.

Access is the key to the nuclear agreement with Iran.  The IAEA, as a part of the Iranian nuclear deal with the Obama administration, was granted access to Iranian nuclear sites under most conditions.  The conditions of the agreement gives Iran some latitude.  The IAEA inspectors must have diplomatic ties with Iran and they have the option to veto specific inspectors.  I see both sides tip-toeing near the boundaries of the agreement while avoiding intervention from the IAEA.  President Trump is beginning to recognize the importance of sovereignty for the Iranian government, and that some intelligence is much better than inaccurate or no intelligence.
I think Iran has a strong incentive to cooperate right now because they can easily present themselves as the victim if trump going ahead with trying to rip up the agreement.

It is very unlikely that Iran will wish to commit an obvious transgression, but a Trumped-up false charge or exaggeration isn't out of the question.  I'll betcha, though, that everybody else in the world is prepared to start (or continue) ignoring the King of Twits in such matters.  This might well precipitate a tantrum during which we shall find out whether the prez can legally withdraw from this agreement without Congressional okey-dokey, but the Joint Commission should be able to sleep tight.

It's in Iran's interests internationally to cooperate, especially if the Trump administration declares it is in violation of JCPOA, as it enables Iran to refute those claims and undermine U.S. legitimacy.
